key_title: Key to the species of Gaudium
notes: Adapted from: Lyne, A. (1996). Leptospermum. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 3. Dicotyledons Winteraceae to Myrtaceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons
Key to the genera of Myrtaceae

leads.lead_text: Hypanthium villous or silky on at least lower half
Leaves 8–15 mm long, 3–5 mm wide, usually yellow-green or light green in colour; ovary 5–8-locular
Leaves 15–30 mm long, 5–10 mm wide, usually grey-green in colour; ovary 7–11-locular
Ovary apex shortly silky all over; plants commonly growing amongst rock or on shallow soils
Ovary apex shortly silky only around base of style and along valve margins; plants usually growing on deep sandy soils

Adult leaves silky on lower surface; young stems without a groove or flange near base of petiole; flowers sessile or pedicel less than 1 mm long; ovary 3-locular; seeds without any loose cells along margins

Adult leaves glabrous (rarely retaining some sparse appressed silky hairs); young stems with a groove or flange present near base of petiole; flowers with pedicel more than 1 mm long; ovary usually 4–6-locular; seeds often with loose cells along margins
Bark on larger stems fibrous, persistent; sepals triangular; fruit 3–4 mm diam
Bark peeling in many papery layers from larger stems; sepals narrowly triangular; fruit 2–3 mm diam
Sepals glabrous on outer surface; leaves incurved, margins occasionally minutely denticulate
Sepals silky on outer surface; leaves flat, margins entire
